section.title: The Economic Point of View
section.p: We begin by supposing that there are no risks. We assume no inflation, and no risk of non-payment. The interest rate in this environment is called the risk-free rate.

introduction.p: Suppose you have some money. There are things you might be interested in purchasing. There are also others who need funds.
If you choose to lend funds to those who need it, the rate you charge is the risk-free rate (recall that there is no risk of inflation or non-payment).

task.p: Explain what is meant by the following statement: "The risk-free rate is compensation to the lender for deferred consumption."

Suppose that there are 1000 potential lenders in the economy. Let r denote the risk-free rate. Let S(r) denote the number of lenders willing to lend at interest rate r. What can you say about S(r)? Explain.
Sketch a possible graph for S(r). This function is the supply curve for money, sometimes called the supply of loanable funds.

introduction.p: Now suppose you do not have money, and would like to purchase something. You can wait, or you can borrow to purchase now.

task.p: What does "deferred consumption" mean on the borrower-side?
Suppose there are 1000 borrowers in the economy. Let D(r) be the number willing to borrow at an interest rate of r. What can you say about D(r)? Explain.
Sketch a possible graph for D(r) This function is the demand curve for money, sometimes called the demand for loanable funds.

statement.p: Sketch your supply and demand curves on the same axes. Label the point at which every one who wants to borrower will be able to do so, and everyone who wants to lend will be able to find a borrower. The rate r at this point is the equilibrium or market rate of interest.
What is the problem if the interest rate is lower than the market rate of interest? What if it is higher?
